    copulaStan: Fitting Bivariate Gaussian and Clayton Copulas

    copulaStan: Fitting Bivariate Gaussian and Clayton Copulas

    copulaStan-intro.Rmd

    Introduction

    In this vignette, we demonstrate how to fit bivariate Gaussian copula models using the copulaStan package. We provide examples for fitting Gaussian copula models with different types of marginals, including normal, and lognormal distributions.

    Example: Gaussian Copula with Normal and Lognormal Marginals 

    library(copulaStan)
library(copula)

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_rho <- 0.5
n <- 2000  

margins <- c("norm", "lnorm")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(meanlog = 0, sdlog = 0.8))
cop <- normalCopula(param = true_rho, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data, copula = "gaussian", marginals = c("normal", "lognormal"), 
                            iter = 4000, chains = 4, warmup = 2000,
                            seed = seed, cores = 4)
fit
    ## Inference for Stan model: anon_model.
## 4 chains, each with iter=4000; warmup=2000; thin=1; 
## post-warmup draws per chain=2000, total post-warmup draws=8000.
## 
##              mean se_mean   sd     2.5%      25%      50%      75%    97.5%
## mu[1]        0.79    0.00 0.05     0.70     0.76     0.79     0.82     0.88
## mu[2]        0.02    0.00 0.02    -0.01     0.01     0.02     0.03     0.06
## sigma[1]     2.03    0.00 0.03     1.97     2.01     2.03     2.06     2.10
## sigma[2]     0.79    0.00 0.01     0.76     0.78     0.79     0.80     0.81
## rho          0.53    0.00 0.02     0.50     0.52     0.53     0.54     0.56
## lp__     -4447.82    0.03 1.61 -4451.80 -4448.62 -4447.47 -4446.64 -4445.73
##          n_eff Rhat

## For each parameter, n_eff is a crude measure of effective sample size,
## and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at 
## convergence, Rhat=1).

    Example: Clayton Copula with Normal and Lognormal Marginals 

    library(copulaStan)
library(copula)

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_theta <- 2.0
n <- 2000  

margins <- c("norm", "lnorm")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(meanlog = 0, sdlog = 0.8))
cop <- claytonCopula(param = true_theta, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data, copula = "clayton", marginals = c("normal", "lognormal"), 
                            iter = 4000, chains = 4, warmup = 2000,
                            seed = seed, cores = 4)
fit
    ## Inference for Stan model: anon_model.
## 4 chains, each with iter=4000; warmup=2000; thin=1; 
## post-warmup draws per chain=2000, total post-warmup draws=8000.
## 
##              mean se_mean   sd     2.5%      25%      50%      75%    97.5%
## mu[1]        0.81    0.00 0.04     0.72     0.78     0.81     0.84     0.89
## mu[2]        0.01    0.00 0.02    -0.02     0.00     0.01     0.02     0.05

## sigma[2]     0.79    0.00 0.01     0.77     0.78     0.79     0.79     0.81

## and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at 
## convergence, Rhat=1).

    Derivation of Gaussian Copula Log Likelihood

    Here is a derivation of the Gaussian copula likelihood implemented in this package.

    Transformation to Uniform Marginals: \[ U_1 = F_1(X_1), \quad U_2 = F_2(X_2) \] where \(F_1\) and \(F_2\) are the CDFs of the marginals.

    Transformation to Standard Normal: \[ Z_1 = \Phi^{-1}(U_1), \quad Z_2 = \Phi^{-1}(U_2) \] where \(\Phi^{-1}\) is the inverse CDF of the standard normal distribution.

    Bivariate Normal Density: \[ \phi_{\rho}(z_1, z_2) = \frac{1}{2\pi\sqrt{1-\rho^2}} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2(1-\rho^2)}(z_1^2 + z_2^2 - 2\rho z_1 z_2) \right) \]

    Standard Normal Marginal Density: \[ \phi(z) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left( -\frac{z^2}{2} \right) \]

    Copula Density: \[ c(u_1, u_2; \rho) = \frac{\phi_{\rho}(z_1, z_2)}{\phi(z_1) \phi(z_2)} \] Substituting the expressions for \(\phi_{\rho}\) and \(\phi\): \[ c(u_1, u_2; \rho) = \frac{\frac{1}{2\pi\sqrt{1-\rho^2}} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2(1-\rho^2)}(z_1^2 + z_2^2 - 2\rho z_1 z_2) \right)}{\left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left( -\frac{z_1^2}{2} \right) \right) \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left( -\frac{z_2^2}{2} \right) \right)} \] Simplifying, we get: \[ c(u_1, u_2; \rho) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\rho^2}} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2(1-\rho^2)}(z_1^2 + z_2^2 - 2\rho z_1 z_2) + \frac{z_1^2}{2} + \frac{z_2^2}{2} \right) \]

    Log Likelihood: \[ \log c(u_1, u_2; \rho) = -\frac{1}{2} \log(1-\rho^2) + \frac{\rho z_1 z_2 - \rho^2 (z_1^2 + z_2^2)}{2(1-\rho^2)} \]

    Derivation of Clayton Copula Log Likelihood

    Here is a derivation of the Clayton copula likelihood implemented in this package.

    The Clayton copula is defined as: \[ C(u, v; \theta) = \left(u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1\right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta}} \] where \(\theta > 0\).

    The copula density function \(c(u, v; \theta)\) is obtained by differentiating the copula function: \[ c(u, v; \theta) = \frac{\partial^2 C(u, v; \theta)}{\partial u \partial v} \]

    First, we differentiate \(C(u, v; \theta)\) with respect to \(u\): \[ \frac{\partial C(u, v; \theta)}{\partial u} = \frac{\partial}{\partial u} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta}} \] \[ = -\frac{1}{\theta} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta} - 1} \cdot (-\theta) u^{-\theta - 1} \] \[ = u^{-\theta - 1} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta} - 1} \]

    Next, we differentiate the result with respect to \(v\): \[ \frac{\partial^2 C(u, v; \theta)}{\partial u \partial v} = \frac{\partial}{\partial v} \left( u^{-\theta - 1} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta} - 1} \right) \] \[ = u^{-\theta - 1} \cdot \left( -\frac{1}{\theta} - 1 \right) \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta} - 2} \cdot (-\theta) v^{-\theta - 1} \] \[ = (\theta + 1) u^{-\theta - 1} v^{-\theta - 1} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta} - 2} \]

    Therefore, the Clayton copula density function is: \[ c(u, v; \theta) = (\theta + 1) u^{-\theta - 1} v^{-\theta - 1} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-\frac{1}{\theta} - 2} \]

    Taking the natural logarithm, we get the log likelihood: \[ \log c(u, v; \theta) = \log(\theta + 1) + (-\theta - 1) (\log u + \log v) + \left( -\frac{1}{\theta} - 2 \right) \log \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right) \] \[ = \log(\theta + 1) + (-\theta - 1) (\log u + \log v) - \left( \frac{2\theta + 1}{\theta} \right) \log \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right) \]

    Thus, the log likelihood of the Clayton copula is: \[ \log c(u, v; \theta) = \log(1 + \theta) + (-\theta - 1) (\log u + \log v) - \frac{2\theta + 1}{\theta} \log (u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1) \]
